lg.l: The wide winds, whose immeasurable hem
Doth touch the seas and star-depths of the soul,
Have swept my sailing bark of thought with them
To many a shore unseen and distant goal;
But now they leave it anchored by the stem
In harbour water where the sands run shoal;
The wistful eyes of beauty nearer home
Seem to reproach that I so far should roam.
‘Twere well, sweet Lake, .Lake. Lake Coleridge/Whakamatau is located in the mountains of the South Island of New Zealand. were I a knight could wield
Good sword, or lift for thee a lance more strong,
To set thy unsung name upon my shield
And make thee mine, as kindred themes belong
To some who bore such blazon to the field;
But I have not yet won my spurs of song;
Admit me of thy beauty the poor squire
Who cannot champion, but must still admire.
Thy native hills crowd countless in the sky;
How rugged are the shores thy smooth waves wet!
Of all this land, the blue and lidless eye
Round whom the mountains for deep brows are met;
I love to see thy many aspects vie:
Thy waters took the sunbeams in their net,
And smote the shingle with short sound and sharp,
Like fingers quickly drawn athwart a harp.
When last my boat skimmed o’er thy shining breast,
Beardless of foam were the light boyish waves;
Instinct with joy and vital with the zest
Of life, we steered her to the harbour caves,
And furled the sail and laid the oars in rest,
And floated on the floor that purely paves
The rarest room, by whose adornment seen
The upholstery of all palaces were mean.

Though cave Broome’s wife, Lady Barker, describes in Station Life in New Zealand (1865) a boating excursion on Lake Coleridge where they entered “a lovely fairy cove” through an overhanging canopy of braches: “It was a sudden contrast from the sparkling sunshine and brightness outside, all life and colour and warmth, to the tender, green, profound shade and quiet in this "Mossy Hum," as the people about here call it.” it was no cavern damp and dark,
But windowed with an opening of its own,
Its mouth contracted to a curious arc
By boughs bent down and thickly overgrown,
Through which the waves burnt lamp-like with a spark
That caught the eye as doth a precious stone;
Though to gaslight and diamonds, I, for one,
Prefer a drop of water and the sun.
Along the walls green ferns were clustered close,
Each leaf a study and each stem a wonder,
In perfect taste, for Nature fastened those,
A builder in her trade not wont to blunder
For ever in the details or the gross,
As is their wont whose work we shelter under—
The roof, half of rough rock, whose clefts and bosses
Were hung with trailing plants or soft with mosses,
And half of trees, whose tough roots hold and hinge
Within the earthless stone, while stretched and stooping
Across, they finish in a feathery fringe,
An archway of the antlered branches, drooping
Towards the sides, so that the waters tinge
The lowest leaves—all interlaced and looping,
And sun-rays slipping through the fair festoons
Fall mellowed, like the light of many moons.
In its far nook was niched a narrow beach
Of pebbles waterworn, a little ledge,
Something for them to break upon and bleach,
The waves had built; o’er which into a wedge
The roof ran down, so that we could not reach
Or bring the boat an oar’s length near its edge:
I know not how, that small short white and bare
Grows on me more than all the greenness there.
Such is this sanctuary of the lake;
And ye who thither have made pilgrimage,
I pray of you, even for its own sweet sake,
To pardon the poor picture of my page—
I know not which with me I’d choose to take
To see it next, some children or a sage;
But this I know, were the last truly such,
Their modes of feeling would not differ much.
